front.title: Trademark Clearinghouse Extension Mapping for the Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP)

abstract.t: This document describes an Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) extension mapping for the provisioning of domain names during the term of rights protection mechanism phases involving the trademark clearinghouse.

section.title: Introduction
section.t: This document describes extensions to the Extensible Provisioning Protocol (EPP) for the operation of domain name registries for the duration of the implementation of rights protection mechanisms that integrate with the trademark clearinghouse.

This document decouples the sunrise and trademark claims processes from the domain name allocation processes used by the registry. The EPP Domain Application Mapping should be considered by registries that require a process allowing multiple applications for one domain name. Appendix A contains an example illustrating the use of the two mappings together in one command.

Readers should be familiar with trademark clearinghouse processes and their implications on registries and the registration process. Access to detailed information on the trademark clearinghouse can be found at [http://newgtlds.icann.org/en/about/trademark-clearinghouse].

section.title: Conventions Used in This Document
section.t: The key words "MUST", "MUST NOT", "REQUIRED", "SHALL", "SHALL NOT", "SHOULD", "SHOULD NOT", "RECOMMENDED", "MAY", and "OPTIONAL" in this document are to be interpreted as described in RFC 2119.

"tmch-1.0" is used as an abbreviation for "urn:ar:params:xml:ns:tmch-1.0". The XML namespace prefix "tmch" is used, but implementations MUST NOT depend on it and instead employ a proper namespace-aware XML parser and serializer to interpret and output the XML documents.

section.title: Trademark Clearinghouse
section.t: The trademark clearinghouse provides several services required by server operators during the launch phases of new TLD registries. Eligible rights holders vetted by the trademark clearinghouse, are given priority in applications for domain names during the sunrise period, and potential registrants are notified of an eligible mark matching their domain name during the trademark claims period.

section.title: Sunrise
section.t: Sunrise is the process by which new TLDs will enable rights holders to have first access to names within a TLD. Only appropriately qualified rights holders are allowed to participate in Sunrise. The scope of qualification is defined in ICANN policy and outside this specification. This specification simply details the mechanism by which this qualification is communicated with the registry using the EPP protocol.
This process requires extension to the <create> command as described below. Requests for registration of a domain name without signed mark data MUST be rejected during the sunrise period.

section.title: Trademark Claims
section.t: Trademark Claims refers to the period during which potential registrants must acknowledge a notice describing one or more entities that have trademarks for the domain names to be registered. Two extensions are required to facilitate this process; the Claims Check is used to determine existence of a claim, and Claims Acknowledgement to provide evidence of acceptance of the claim on registration.

section.title: Claims Check
section.t: This process requires extension to the <check> command and response as described below. A check response during this stage indicates whether a claim exists, and includes the relevant claims key used by the client for retrieval of claims information from the trademark clearinghouse.

section.title: Claims Acknowledgment
section.t: This process requires extension to the <create> command as described below. Registrations for domain names matching a claim MUST be rejected unless the claims acknowledgement is provided.

section.title: Object Attributes
section.t: This extension adds additional elements to the EPP Domain Name Mapping. Only those new elements are described here.

section.title: Signed Mark Data
section.t: Signed mark data (SMD) is the information published by the trademark clearinghouse as proof of validation and applicability for participation in the sunrise phase, and signed to verify authenticity.

The SMD is defined in [draft-lozano-smd], and is represented in a file as described in [draft-func-spec]. This extension requires the SMD be transmitted to the server encoded using Base64 for two reasons:
XML Signature validation is sensitive to changes in whitespace and formatting and a signed document may become invalid if treated as text, such as in emails or log files.
It is known that registry operators have implemented their EPP XML processing using SAX parsers, however signature validation libraries require a DOM parser. This specification should not require server operators change their XML parser.

section.title: Claims Lookup Key
section.t: The claims lookup key is an identifier returned by the server in response to a <tmch:check> command and used for the lookup of claims notice information in the trademark clearinghouse. The lookup key is defined in [draft-func-spec].

section.title: Notice Identifier
section.t: The notice identifier is obtained by the client requesting the claims notice from the trademark clearinghouse using the aforementioned claims key. The notice identifier is a unique identifier assigned by the TMCH to each trademark claims notice. The notice identifier is described in [draft-func-spec].

section.title: Dates and Times
section.t: Date and time attribute values MUST be represented in Universal Coordinated Time (UTC) using the Gregorian calendar. The extended date-time form using upper case "T" and "Z" characters defined in [W3C.REC-xmlschema-2-20041028] MUST be used to represent date-time values, as XML Schema does not support truncated date-time forms or lower case "T" and "Z" characters.

section.title: EPP Command Mapping
section.t: A detailed description of the EPP syntax and semantics can be found in the EPP core protocol specification . The command mappings described here are specifically for use in the Trademark Clearinghouse Extension.

section.title: EPP Query Commands
section.t: EPP provides three commands to retrieve object information: <check> to determine if an object is known to the server, <info> to retrieve detailed information associated with an object, and <transfer> to retrieve object transfer status information.

section.title: EPP <check> Command
section.t: This extension defines additional elements to extend the EPP <check> command and response to be used in conjunction with the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

To enable clients to identify domain names that are subject to claims processing, the <domain:check> command is extended with a <tmch:check> element, which signals a client's intention to retrieve claims information.

When a <check> command containing the <tmch:check> element has been processed successfully, the server MUST NOT respond with the <domain:chkData> element described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping. Instead, servers must respond with a <tmch:chkData> element that contains one <tmch:cd> element for each domain name present in the command. The <tmch:cd> element contains the following child elements:
A <tmch:name> element containing a domain name from the corresponding command. The order and composition of domain names in the response MUST be the same as the order and composition of domain names provided in the command, with exception to transformations required of validating XML parsers. A mandatory "claim" attribute describes whether a claim exists for this name.
A <tmch:key> element containing the claims key used for retrieval of the claims data. This element MUST be present during the Trademark Claims period where the <tmch:name> element's "claim" attribute evaluates to true.

figure.preamble: Example <check> response during the trademark claims period
figure.artwork: <?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?> <epp xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:epp-1.0"> <response> <result code="1000"> <msg>Command completed successfully</msg> </result> <extension> <chkData xmlns="urn:ar:params:xml:ns:tmch-1.0"> <cd> <name claim="1">example.tld</name> <key>CLAIM_KEY</key> </cd> </chkData> </extension> <trID> <clTRID>ABC-12345</clTRID> <svTRID>54321-XYZ</svTRID> </trID> </response> </epp>

section.title: EPP <info> Command
section.t: This extension defines additional elements to extend the EPP <info> command and response to be used in conjunction with the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

To enable clients to view the SMD associated with domain names, the <domain:info> command is extended with a <tmch:info> element, which signals a client's intention to retrieve associated SMD information.

When an <info> command containing the <tmch:info> element has been processed successfully, the server extends the response with a <tmch:infData> element that contains one <tmch:smd> element that contains the SMD.

figure.preamble: Example <info> response containing the SMD associated with the domain.
figure.artwork: <?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?> <epp xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:epp-1.0"> <response> <result code="1000"> <msg>Command completed successfully</msg> </result> <resData> section.title: EPP <transfer> Command
section.t: This extension does not define any extension to the EPP <transfer> command or response described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

section.title: EPP Transform Commands
section.t: EPP provides five commands to transform objects: <create> to create an instance of an object, <delete> to delete an instance of an object, <renew> to extend the validity period of an object, <transfer> to manage object sponsorship changes, and <update> to change information associated with an object.

section.title: EPP <create> Command
section.t: There are two forms of the extension to the EPP <create> command that are dependent on the whether the server is operating a sunrise or TM claims process. Both forms are described below.

section.title: Sunrise Domain Create
section.t: The Sunrise Create extension to the EPP Domain Name Mapping includes the verifiable trademark information that the server uses to match against the domain name to authorize the domain create.

To enable clients to register domain names during the sunrise phase, the <domain:create> command is extended with a <tmch:create> element that contains the following child elements:
A <tmch:smd> element that contains the base-64 encoded signed mark data.

section.title: TM Claims Domain Create
section.t: The Claims Create extension to the EPP Domain Name Mapping includes the information related to the acceptance of the claims notice for the TM Claims period.

To enable clients to create domain names during the trademark claims phase, the <domain:create> command is extended with a <tmch:create> element that contains the following child elements:
A <noticeID> element that contains the unique notice identifier generated by the Claims Notice Information Service (CNIS).
A <notAfter> element that contains the latest date and time up to which the claims notice can be used to register a domain name or domain application.
A <accepted> element that contains the date and time that the claims notice was accepted.

figure.preamble: Example <create> during the TM Claims period.
figure.artwork: <?xml version="1.0" standalone="no"?> <epp xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:epp-1.0"> <command> <create> <create xmlns="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:domain-1.0"> <name>example.tld</name> <registrant>jd1234</registrant> <contact type="admin">sh8013</contact> <contact type="tech">sh8013</contact> <authInfo> <pw>2fooBAR</pw> </authInfo> </create> </create> <extension> <create xmlns="urn:ar:params:xml:ns:tmch-1.0"> <noticeID>49FD46E6C4B45C55D4AC</noticeID> <notAfter>2012-06-20T09:00:00.0Z</notAfter> <accepted>2012-06-19T09:00:10.0Z</accepted> </create> </extension> <clTRID>ABC-12345</clTRID> </command> </epp>

section.title: EPP <delete> Command
section.t: This extension does not define any extension to the EPP <delete> command or response described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

section.title: EPP <renew> Command
section.t: This extension does not define any extension to the EPP <renew> command or response described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

section.title: EPP <transfer> Command
section.t: This extension does not define any extension to the EPP <transfer> command or response described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

section.title: EPP <update> Command
section.t: This extension does not define any extension to the EPP <update> command or response described in the EPP Domain Name Mapping.

figure.artwork:
<?xml version="1.0"?> <schema targetNamespace="urn:ar:params:xml:ns:tmch-1.0" xmlns:tmch="urn:ar:params:xml:ns:tmch-1.0" xmlns:eppcom="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:eppcom-1.0" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" elementFormDefault="qualified">
<import namespace="urn:ietf:params:xml:ns:eppcom-1.0" />
<!-- Custom command extensions --> <element name="check" /> <element name="create" type="tmch:createType" /> <element name="info" />
<complexType name="createType"> <choice> <element name="smd" type="tmch:smdType"> </element> <sequence> <element name="noticeID" type="token" /> <element name="notAfter" type="dateTime" /> <element name="accepted" type="dateTime" /> </sequence> </choice> </complexType>
<simpleType name="smdType"> <restriction base="base64Binary"> <minLength value="1" /> </restriction> </simpleType>
<!-- Custom response extensions for checkbis extension --> <element name="chkData" type="tmch:chkDataType" /> <element name="infData" type="tmch:infDataType" />
<complexType name="chkDataType"> <sequence> <element name="cd" type="tmch:checkType" maxOccurs="unbounded" /> </sequence> </complexType>
<complexType name="checkType"> <sequence> <element name="name" type="tmch:checkNameType" /> <element name="key" type="normalizedString" minOccurs="0" /> </sequence> </complexType>
<complexType name="checkNameType"> <simpleContent> <extension base="eppcom:labelType"> <attribute name="claim" type="boolean" use="required" /> </extension> </simpleContent> </complexType>
<complexType name="infDataType"> <sequence> <element name="smd" type="tmch:smdType" minOccurs="0" /> </sequence> </complexType>
</schema>

section.title: Security Considerations
section.t: The mapping extensions described in this document do not provide any security services beyond those described by EPP, the EPP Domain Name Mapping, and protocol layers used by EPP. The security considerations described in these other specifications apply to this specification as well.

section.title: TMCH Sunrise Domain Application Example
section.t: Example showing creating an application for a domain name during the sunrise period. Additional extensions, such as IDN may be included as required by the server.
